questions.question: What symbol is on the Canadian flag?
questions.explanation: The Canadian flag features a stylized red maple leaf on a white square with red bars on either side. It was officially adopted in 1965.

questions.question: Who is Canada's Head of State?
questions.explanation: As a constitutional monarchy, Canada's Head of State is the King (currently King Charles III). The Crown has been a symbol of the state in Canada for 400 years.

questions.question: What is Canada's national motto?
options: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness
A Mari usque ad Mare (From Sea to Sea)
questions.correctAnswer: A Mari usque ad Mare (From Sea to Sea)
questions.explanation: Canada's national motto is 'A Mari usque ad Mare,' which in Latin means 'From Sea to Sea.' It was adopted after the First World War as an expression of national pride.
questions.reference: Discover Canada, p. 38-39, 'Coat of arms and motto'

questions.question: What was the first flag used widely as a Canadian symbol?
questions.explanation: The Canadian Red Ensign served as Canada's flag for about 100 years before the current Maple Leaf flag was adopted in 1965.

questions.question: What is the significance of the maple leaf as a Canadian symbol?
options: It represents the maple syrup industry
It was adopted by French Canadians in the 1700s and has appeared on Canadian uniforms since the 1850s
It represents the strength of the Canadian economy
questions.correctAnswer: It was adopted by French Canadians in the 1700s and has appeared on Canadian uniforms since the 1850s
questions.explanation: The maple leaf has a long history as a Canadian symbol. It was adopted by French Canadians in the 1700s, has appeared on Canadian uniforms since the 1850s, and is carved into the headstones of fallen Canadian soldiers.

questions.question: What is the significance of the fleur-de-lis in Canada?
options: It appears on Canada's national flag
It is a symbol of British heritage
It was a symbol of French royalty and appears on Quebec's flag
questions.correctAnswer: It was a symbol of French royalty and appears on Quebec's flag
questions.explanation: The fleur-de-lis was adopted by the French king in 496 and became the symbol of French royalty for over 1,000 years, including in New France. It is prominently featured on Quebec's flag, adopted in 1948.

questions.question: What animal is considered a symbol of Canada and appears on the five-cent coin?
questions.explanation: The beaver was adopted centuries ago as a symbol of the Hudson's Bay Company and can be seen on the five-cent coin. It's considered an emblem of industriousness and perseverance.

questions.question: What are the official languages of Canada?
questions.explanation: English and French are the two official languages of Canada and important symbols of identity. Parliament passed the Official Languages Act in 1969 to establish equality between the two languages.

questions.question: When was the current Canadian flag, featuring a maple leaf, officially adopted?
questions.explanation: The current Canadian flag featuring a red maple leaf was raised for the first time in 1965, replacing the Canadian Red Ensign.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Peace Tower in Ottawa?
options: It was built to celebrate Confederation
It was completed in 1927 in memory of the First World War
It represents the peace treaty with the United States
questions.correctAnswer: It was completed in 1927 in memory of the First World War
questions.explanation: The Peace Tower was completed in 1927 in memory of the First World War. The Memorial Chamber within the tower contains Books of Remembrance listing the names of those who died serving Canada in wars.

questions.question: What is Canada's national winter sport?
questions.explanation: Hockey is Canada's most popular spectator sport and is considered to be the national winter sport. It was developed in Canada in the 1800s.

questions.question: What trophy is awarded to the champion team of the National Hockey League?
questions.explanation: The National Hockey League plays for the championship Stanley Cup, donated by Lord Stanley, the Governor General, in 1892.

questions.question: What is the highest honor available to Canadians for bravery?
questions.explanation: The Victoria Cross (V.C.) is the highest honor available to Canadians and is awarded for the most conspicuous bravery, a daring or pre-eminent act of valour or self-sacrifice, or extreme devotion to duty in the presence of the enemy.

questions.question: When was the Order of Canada established?
questions.explanation: After using British honours for many years, Canada started its own honours system with the Order of Canada in 1967, the centennial year of Confederation.
questions.reference: Discover Canada, p. 40, 'The Order of Canada and other honours'

questions.question: What is the first line of Canada's national anthem in English?
options: O Canada! Our home and native land!
O Canada! Terre de nos a√Øeux!
From far and wide, O Canada
questions.correctAnswer: O Canada! Our home and native land!
questions.explanation: The first line of 'O Canada' in English is 'O Canada! Our home and native land!' The anthem was officially proclaimed as the national anthem in 1980, although it was first sung in Quebec City in 1880.

questions.question: What is the Royal Anthem of Canada?
questions.explanation: The Royal Anthem of Canada is 'God Save the Queen' (or 'God Save the King' when the monarch is male). It can be played or sung on any occasion when Canadians wish to honor the Sovereign.

questions.question: Which flag is Canada's official Royal Flag?
questions.explanation: The Union Jack is Canada's official Royal Flag, reflecting Canada's history as part of the British Empire and its continued status as a constitutional monarchy.

questions.question: Where are the books of Remembrance kept?
questions.explanation: The Memorial Chamber within the Peace Tower contains the Books of Remembrance, in which are written the names of soldiers, sailors and airmen who died serving Canada in wars or while on duty.

questions.question: What is the official summer sport of Canada?
questions.explanation: Lacrosse, an ancient sport first played by Aboriginal peoples, is Canada's official summer sport.

questions.question: What flower symbol is associated with Remembrance Day?
questions.explanation: The poppy is worn on Remembrance Day to honor the sacrifice of Canadians who have served or died in wars up to the present day.

questions.question: What year was the Parliament Buildings Centre Block destroyed by fire and subsequently rebuilt?
questions.explanation: The Centre Block of the Parliament Buildings was destroyed by an accidental fire in 1916 and rebuilt in 1922. The Library is the only part of the original building remaining.

questions.question: What is the origin of the red-white-red pattern on the Canadian flag?
options: It represents the British and French heritage
It comes from the flag of the Royal Military College, Kingston
It symbolizes peace, unity, and prosperity
It was designed through a national contest
questions.correctAnswer: It comes from the flag of the Royal Military College, Kingston
questions.explanation: The red-white-red pattern on the Canadian flag comes from the flag of the Royal Military College, Kingston, founded in 1876. Red and white had been colours of France and England since the Middle Ages and became the national colours of Canada in 1921.

questions.question: What is featured on Canada's Coat of Arms?
options: Symbols of England, France, Scotland, Ireland, and red maple leaves
questions.correctAnswer: Symbols of England, France, Scotland, Ireland, and red maple leaves
questions.explanation: Canada's Coat of Arms contains symbols of England, France, Scotland, and Ireland, as well as red maple leaves. It was adopted after the First World War as an expression of national pride.
questions.reference: Discover Canada, p. 38, 'Coat of arms and motto'

questions.question: What are the three objectives of the Official Languages Act passed in 1969?
options: To promote tourism, trade, and immigration
To establish equality between French and English in Parliament and government, maintain official language minority communities, and promote equality of French and English in society
To ensure all Canadians speak both languages, provide interpretation services, and collect language statistics
To create jobs, protect culture, and support education
questions.correctAnswer: To establish equality between French and English in Parliament and government, maintain official language minority communities, and promote equality of French and English in society
questions.explanation: The Official Languages Act has three main objectives: establish equality between French and English in Parliament and government institutions; maintain and develop official language minority communities; and promote equality of French and English in Canadian society.

questions.question: In what year did the maple leaf flag first fly in Canada?
questions.explanation: A new Canadian flag with the red maple leaf design was raised for the first time in 1965.

questions.question: What symbol appears on the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) badge?
questions.explanation: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) badge features a buffalo head, representing the force's origins in the Canadian West.

questions.question: What flower is a symbol of Ontario?
questions.explanation: The white trillium is the official floral emblem of Ontario.

questions.question: What flower is a symbol of Quebec?
questions.explanation: The white garden lily (fleur-de-lis) is Quebec's floral emblem, and the stylized fleur-de-lis also appears on Quebec's flag.

questions.question: What tree is considered a symbol of Canada?
questions.explanation: The maple tree, particularly the sugar maple, is a Canadian symbol, with its leaf appearing on the national flag and the coat of arms.

questions.question: What symbol is used on Canadian coins that feature Queen Elizabeth II?
questions.explanation: Canadian coins typically feature the portrait of the reigning monarch on one side. Coins minted during Queen Elizabeth II's reign feature her portrait.

questions.question: What does the maple leaf on Canada's flag represent?
questions.explanation: The maple leaf on Canada's flag represents Canadian identity and unity, a symbol recognized around the world.

questions.question: When is Canada Day celebrated?
questions.explanation: Canada Day is celebrated on July 1, commemorating the anniversary of Confederation in 1867 when the British North America Act united the three colonies into a single country.

questions.question: What types of leaves are shown on the Canadian coat of arms?
questions.explanation: The Canadian coat of arms features both maple leaves (representing Canada) and oak leaves (representing England), reflecting Canada's historical ties.

questions.question: What animals appear on the Canadian coat of arms?
questions.explanation: The Canadian coat of arms features a lion (representing England) on the viewer's left and a unicorn (representing Scotland) on the right.

questions.question: What is the design on the reverse side of the Canadian penny coin?
questions.explanation: The modern Canadian penny (one-cent coin), before it was discontinued in 2012, featured two maple leaves on a common twig on its reverse side.

questions.question: What is the official national tartan of Canada?
questions.explanation: The Maple Leaf Tartan was declared the official national tartan of Canada in 2011. Its colors reflect the changing colors of maple leaves through the seasons.

questions.question: What does the word 'Canada' mean in Iroquoian language?
questions.explanation: The name 'Canada' is derived from the Iroquoian word 'kanata', which means 'village' or 'settlement'.

questions.question: When did Canada celebrate its 150th anniversary?
questions.explanation: Canada celebrated its 150th anniversary of Confederation in 2017, marking 150 years since the British North America Act of 1867.

questions.question: What is the significance of the red and white colors on the Canadian flag?
options: They represent the Indigenous and European peoples
They were King George V's favorite colors
They were proclaimed Canada's national colours by King George V in 1921
They represent Canada's two founding nations
questions.correctAnswer: They were proclaimed Canada's national colours by King George V in 1921
questions.explanation: Red and white were proclaimed Canada's national colors by King George V in 1921, and these colors were later used in the national flag adopted in 1965.

questions.question: What image appears on the Canadian $10 bill?
questions.explanation: Viola Desmond, a civil rights activist who challenged racial segregation in Nova Scotia in 1946, appears on the Canadian $10 bill issued in 2018.

questions.question: What is the ceremonial mace in Parliament a symbol of?
questions.explanation: The ceremonial mace in Parliament is a symbol of royal authority. The House of Commons cannot legally meet unless the mace is present.

questions.question: Which of these buildings houses the Senate of Canada?
questions.explanation: Since 2019, during Centre Block renovations, the Senate has been housed in the Senate of Canada Building (formerly the Government Conference Centre).

questions.question: Which landmark in Ottawa is a symbol of remembrance for fallen Canadian soldiers?
questions.explanation: The National War Memorial in Ottawa is a cenotaph symbolizing the sacrifice of all Canadian Armed Forces personnel who have served Canada in time of war and lost their lives in service to their country.
